message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the use of hydralazine suggest drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Anti-histone antibodies are commonly found in DILE. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are more commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) while anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset fever, malaise, and pain and swelling in the joints suggest drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE), which can be caused by hydralazine. Anti-histone antibodies are commonly seen in patients with DILE. Anti-dsDNA and Anti-Smith are seen in systemic lupus erythematosus, while Anti-β2-glycoprotein is seen in antiphospholipid syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history of hydralazine use suggest drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Among the options, anti-histone antibodies are most commonly associated with DILE.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and recent use of hydralazine suggest that drug-induced lupus erythematosus is the most likely diagnosis. Anti-histone antibodies are commonly seen in drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Anti-dsDNA, Anti-Smith, and Anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies are associated with other autoimmune disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the medication history suggest drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Hydralazine is a common cause of DILE and is associated with positive anti-histone antibodies. Therefore, the most likely increased autoantibody in this case is anti-histone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE), which is associated with the use of hydralazine. Among the options, only anti-histone antibodies are more commonly associated with DILE.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest drug-induced lupus, commonly associated with the use of hydralazine. Anti-histone antibodies are present in more than 90% of patients with drug-induced lupus. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith are more common in systemic lupus erythematosus. Anti-β2-glycoprotein may be elevated in antiphospholipid syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the sudden onset after starting a new medication, suggest drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Hydralazine is known to cause drug-induced lupus erythematosus, and a positive anti-histone antibody test is often seen in drug-induced lupus erythematosus. The other autoantibodies listed are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest drug-induced lupus erythematosus, which is commonly associated with anti-histone antibodies. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are more commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, and anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest drug-induced lupus erythematosus, which is associated with a positive anti-histone antibody test. The other autoantibodies listed are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, which is a different disease.
